frameDefinitions: A Money_owner exchanges Sum_1 in the  Source_currency for Sum_2 in the Target_currency at some Exchange_service.
Two parties, the Exchangers, each give and receive from the other Themes.
An Agent or Cause causes an Entity to change, either in its category membership or in terms of the value of an Attribute.
An Agent changes Tools, from the Old_tool to a New_tool.
An Agent changes the filler of a  Role by placing a New filler in the position after the Old filler ceases to occupy the position.
frameExamples: After checking into the Intourist-operated $30-a-day Hotel Zerafshon, we each <t>exchanged</t> $50 for Uzbek currency with a shifty loiterer in the lobby at the rate .
They <t>swapped</t> the island with the Neapolitan government of the day for the much smaller Capri.
Our storylines follows the saga outlined by the Ultima Series, but we have <t>modified</t> it in order to make our writing more cohesive.
If this happens one more time, we 're going to <t>switch</t> operating systems.
If you <t>replace</t> me with a robot, who's gonna make excuses to your wife for you?
listRoleDefinitions: The person who exchanges <fen>Sum_1</fen> for <fen>Sum_2</fen>.
An amount of money in the <fen>Source_currency</fen> that the <fen>Money_owner</fen> exchanges for an amount in the <fen>Target_currency</fen>.
The kind of currency of the <fen>Money_owner</fen> has before the exchange.
The amount of money in the <fen>Target_currency</fen> that the <fen>Money_owner</fen> receives in exchange for <fen>Sum_1</fen>.
The kind of currency that the <fen>Money_owner</fen> receives as part of the exchange.
Currency that is being exchanged by the <fen>Money_owner</fen>.
The time when the currency is exchanged.
The location where the money is exchanged.

In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational
participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as
compared with <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Exchanger_1</fen> is generally
encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference
to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>. Thus
a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that
of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> or the group
of <fen>Exchangers</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> refers to the semantically
and grammatically less prominent group. It is generally encoded
within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with). Note that it
is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents.
For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were
plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Exchangers</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Exchangers</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Exchange frame, it is possible for the <fen>Exchangers</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.
The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>.
The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.
The items which change possession between the <fen>Exchangers</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the exchange takes place.
This role identifies the place where the exchange occurs.
The sentient entity that effects a change in the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The category of which the <fen>Entity</fen> is a member before the <fen>Agent</fen> causes a change.
The category that the <fen>Entity</fen> belongs to after it has undergone the change.
The value that the <fen>Attribute</fen> assumes as a result of the change that the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused to undergo.
The value that the <fen>Attribute</fen> has before the change takes place.
The abstract or concrete thing or situation that the <fen>Agent</fen> causes to change.
The time at which the change of the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused.
The location where the change of the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused.
The individual that changes their situation.
The entities controlled by an Agent to achieve some Purpose.
The tool that the <fen>Agent</fen> had been using.
The tool that the <fen>Agent</fen> ends up using.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> acts intentionally.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Agent</fen> makes a change.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs actions resulting in the <fen>New</fen> entity occupying the position.
The <fen>New</fen> entity is the person or thing that the <fen>Agent</fen> sets to fill a <fen>Role</fen>.
The entity that formerly occupied the position.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> installs the New entity.
This role identifies where the <fen>Agent</fen> installs the <fen>New</fen> entity.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Kornfeldt</fex> hurried through customs, grabbed a city map at a tourist information desk, changed $40 USD into about 300 Hong Kong dollars before leaving the airport
I said forget it and just exchanged <fex>$40 US cash</fex> into $47 and change in Canadian.
We stopped at a bank were we exchanged <fex>Euros</fex> for Danish money.
On the bus we exchanged $50 <fex>for 1410 rubles</fex>.
We had exchanged $100 <fex>into francs</fex> in LAX to be able to pay for the cab ride upon arrival.
I exchanged $1000 <fex>of my money</fex> at the bank.
We walked around Eyre Square and exchanged money <fex>before walking into Taaffes pub and grabbing my first draught pint of Guinness of the trip</fex>.
I exchanged $100 <fex>in Croatia</fex> because i needed a round trip bus ticket to sarajevo.
The trade <fex>with Cuba</fex> went exactly as planned.
<fex>Smithers and Kornfeldt</fex> traded Pez dispensers.
I tucked the pistol between my belt and tunic top (how I wish I had kept it, but I later swapped <fex>it</fex> with a Canadian for some cigarettes.
The organization bought the property in 1999, then swapped it with the BLM <fex>for about 100 parcels in 10 counties ranging in size from one to 920 acres</fex>.
They swapped <fex>guitars</fex>.
<fex>The system administrator</fex> changed the value from 'KDE' to 'GNOME', and then restarted the system.
Her time with the Healer Craft has changed her <fex>from a shy, nervous young girl</fex> into a confident (almost) young woman
The radical message of the cross transformed Saul of Tarsus and changed him from a persecutor of Christians <fex>to a tender believer</fex>.
We changed the size from 8 1/2x11 <fex>to a larger 11 x 17</fex> and gave it a complete graphical makeover.
My dad changed his hair color <fex>from red</fex>  to blue today.
The recent terrorist attacks had changed <fex>the political climate</fex>.
He changed it <fex>after David Bowie told him that only twerps have the same first and last name</fex>.
<fex>In his own room</fex> he had modified nothing.
I don't know; perhaps you could substitute <fex>regular sugar</fex>.
If you substitute a 15' arm <fex>for the 50cm one</fex>, it works pretty well.
